entry.title: Re: How to utilize SuccessFactors reports like canvas, story
entry.content:
Hi vishwaN45

To report on modules like RCM, ONB, and EC in SuccessFactors, you can use two main tools:

Story Reports:  This is ideal for dashboards and cross module insights and it is best used with EC data. RCM and ONB data may require you to integrate or replicate. These are built in Report Center à Story and require People Analytics to be enabled.

Canvas Reports: This is best for tabular or compliance reports and still commonly used for RCM and ONB. It is built via Report Centerà Report Canvas using Detailed Reporting.

I recommend you use Story Reports for new developments and Canvas where module specific live data or advanced logic is needed.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Need Help Mapping Tax Entries to Supplier Invoice Ite...
entry.content:
Hello,

Thank you very much for your question.

Can you please check whether the following information helps to solve your issue? (GenAI was used to help generate this content)

To address the challenges in developing a custom Purchase Register report in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, consider the following approaches:

Suggested CDS Views and Techniques

  1. Custom CDS Views: You might need to create custom CDS views to establish the necessary linkages between invoice items and tax entries. This involves:

    • Using the Custom CDS Views app Creating Custom CDS Views and Analytical Query - A Step-by-Step Guide to define new views that join existing CDS views like I_OperationalAcctgDocItem and I_SupplierInvoiceTaxAPI01.
    • Incorporating additional fields or logic to capture ineligible tax amounts and segregate freight and asset item taxes.

  2. Join Conditions: Ensure that your custom CDS views have appropriate join conditions to link tax entries with invoice items. This might involve:

    • Using fields like InvoiceItemNumber and TaxCode to establish relationships between invoice items and tax lines.
    • Implementing logic to handle cases where multiple tax lines correspond to a single invoice item, especially for asset purchases.

Best Practices

  • Parameter Definition: Define parameters at the lowest level in your CDS view workflow to improve performance and ensure accurate data retrieval.
  • Avoid Nested Associations: Instead of using nested associations, create separate CDS views for complex joins and then combine them at a higher level.
  • Aggregation Methods: For fields with type measure, define aggregation methods to ensure accurate calculations in your reports.
Creating Custom CDS Views and Analytical Query - A Step-by-Step Guide
SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition - Key User Extensibility In-App

Kind regards,

Henrike

entry.title: Re: Impact of activating the following Business Functions
entry.content:
Hi @rgap 

Thanks for your question.

Activating the business functions LOG_MM_P2PSE_1, ESOA_OPS01, LOG_ESOA_OPS_2, and LOG_MM_CI_2 in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud introduces enhancements in procurement, logistics enterprise services, and purchasing processes. Once they are activated, these functions cannot be reversed. While system performance impact is minimal, these following considerations are very important:

  • You might experience changes to your procurement workflows and data flows
  • You might activate new APIs and enterprise service 
  • You will have to carry out regression testing before production deployment

I suggest you use the Scope and Dependency Tool and testing end-to-end processes to ensure compatibility with your current setup.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: BADI MRM_CHECK_INVOICE_CLOUD implementation at Save a...
entry.content:
The BAdI MRM_CHECK_INVOICE_CLOUD is designed to allow custom checks on supplier invoice header and item data. It’s part of the Invoice Verification (MM-IV) component and is triggered during invoice processing.  Check this SAP Help documentation.

Why your Implementation may not be triggered could be

  • due to wrong action hook. Ensure your implementation is assigned to the correct action hook. For “Save as Completed,” the BAdI must be configured to trigger during that specific action — not just during “Check” or “Post.”
  • In SAP Public Cloud you must use the Custom Logic app in Fiori to implement and activate the BAdI. Ensure your logic is deployed and active. Use the Business Context: Procurement: Supplier Invoice.

Additionally, this BAdI does not access external master data (e.g., supplier limits) unless you expose that data via custom logic or APIs. You may need to store approver limits in a custom table or use workflow context if available. Check this SAP Business Accelator Hub – MRM_CHECK_INVOICE_CLOUD

entry.content:
Hi @Achana_Bisoyi 

Thanks for your query and screenshot examples.

Please note, currently, JavaScript within the Adobe form only runs in preview mode and doesn’t execute during live printing from SAP, so the logic isn’t applied in runtime. The correct and supported approach is to perform the number‑to‑text conversion on the backend using the standard function module SPELL_AMOUNT or a country specific version.

You should implement this conversion logic in the form’s data provider or feeder class and then pass the resulting text to the form. This ensures the amount‑in‑words displays correctly at runtime.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Chris

entry.title: Re: A record needs to change during go-live over DNS Switch
entry.content:
Migrating SAP systems with High Availability configurations, such as Windows Server Failover Clustering  for SAP Central Services and Always-On Availability Groups  for MSSQL, requires careful planning and execution. Here’s a detailed approach to ensure a smooth migration while retaining the same WSFC Cluster Names and MSSQL AG listener names:

### Preparation

1. **Backup:**
- Ensure you have complete backups of your SAP systems, databases, and configurations.

2. **Pre-Migration Checks:**
- Verify that the target VMs meet the requirements for SAP, WSFC, and AOAG.
- Ensure that the target VMs are part of the same Active Directory  domain and DNS server.

### VM Migration

1. **Set Up Target VMs:**
- Provision the target VMs in Azure with the same specifications as the source VMs.
- Install the necessary operating system and SAP software on the target VMs.

2. **WSFC Configuration:**
- Install and configure WSFC on the target VMs.
- Ensure that the cluster name and IP address are the same as the source WSFC cluster.

3. **AOAG Configuration:**
- Set up MSSQL on the target VMs and configure AOAG.
- Ensure that the AG listener name and IP address are the same as the source AOAG configuration.

### Hostname and DNS Configuration

1. **Hostname Configuration:**
- Configure the target VMs to use the same hostnames as the source VMs.

2. **DNS Update:**
- During the cutover, update the DNS records to point to the new IP addresses of the target VMs.
- Remove the old A records for the source VMs and create new A records for the target VMs with the same hostnames.

### Migration Steps

1. **SAP Central Services Migration:**
- Stop the SAP Central Services on the source VMs.
- Start the SAP Central Services on the target VMs within the WSFC cluster.

2. **Database Migration:**
- Ensure that the MSSQL databases are synchronized between the source and target VMs.
- Switch the AOAG to the target VMs and verify that the AG listener name resolves correctly.

### Testing

1. **Verify Hostname Resolution:**
- Ensure that the hostnames resolve correctly to the new IP addresses of the target VMs.

2. **SAP Functionality Testing:**
- Perform thorough testing of SAP applications and services to ensure they are functioning correctly on the target VMs.
- Test the failover functionality of WSFC and AOAG to ensure HA configurations are working as expected.

### Finalization

1. **Monitor Post-Migration:**
- Monitor the system closely for any issues that may arise post-migration.
- Ensure that all SAP services, WSFC, and AOAG configurations are stable and functioning correctly.

By following these steps and leveraging the available resources, you should be able to successfully migrate your SAP systems while retaining the same WSFC Cluster Names and MSSQL AG listener names.

entry.title: Re: 如何通过自定义逻辑来限制供应商发票的多次暂存
entry.content:
您好，

根据您给的需求，我这里提供一段样例代码。供参考，实际使用需要根据自己的业务进行测试和修正。

经过测试，相同 PO + ITEM + 收货，如果已经过账，下次无法再选到这条收货凭证进行重复暂存。所以这里我采用作校验条件的字段是 PO 和 ITEM 号。同时，因为要校验这个 PO 和 ITEM 是否已经过账，所以要用到 I_SupplierInvoiceAPI01 里的 SUPPLIERINVOICESTATUS = '5' 。但是这个 CDS View 里没有 PO 和 ITEM 这两个字段，所以我们需要用到原来代码里的 I_SuplrInvcItemPurOrdRefAPI01 。在我的示例代码里，我用到了一个自定义 CDS View ，您可以在自己的系统里基于 I_SupplierInvoiceAPI01 创建自定义 CDS View ，选中对应字段，进行基本调整。

loop at ITEMSWITHPOREFERENCE REFERENCE INTO DATA(Supinvoice_item).
if action = if_ex_mrm_check_invoice_cloud=>c_Action_Hold.
    select single @abap_true
    from YY1_I_SUPPLIERINVOICEAPI01 with privileged access
    where PURCHASEORDER = @Supinvoice_item->PURCHASEORDER and PURCHASEORDERITEM = @Supinvoice_item->PURCHASEORDERITEM
    and SUPPLIERINVOICESTATUS = '5'
    into @DATA(Is_Supinvoice_status) .
    if Is_Supinvoice_status = abap_true.
      append value #( messagetype = 'E' messageid = 'MRM_BADI_CLOUD' messagenumber = '001' messagevariable1 = '暂存的发票有重复项目。' ) to messages.
    endif.
endif.
endloop.

祝好，

Zhehui

entry.title: Re: Is it possible to separate the calculation of interes...
entry.content:
This requirement is not achievable through standard FINT alone — it needs:

  • Custom interest indicators
  • Possibly enhancement via user exits or BAdIs
  • Careful configuration of posting rules and document splitting

SAP allows you to define multiple interest indicators in customizing:

Go to SPRO → Financial Accounting → Accounts Receivable and Accounts Payable → Business Transactions → Interest Calculation → Define Interest Indicators. There, create separate indicators for:

  1. Interest (e.g., ZINT)
  2. Surcharge (e.g., ZSUR)

You can then assign different rates and posting keys to each.

If you're working in Contract Accounting (FI-CA), you can use Events 2010, 2020, 2030 to split interest and surcharge logic, Customize posting behavior, Generate separate accounting documents or line items. This is done via ABAP enhancements in the respective event modules.

In FI-CA interest calculation, you can activate the Single Document indicator. This forces SAP to create separate FI documents for each interest item, helps in isolating interest vs. surcharge amounts. More details are available in SAP’s Executing Interest Calculations guide

entry.title: Re: Alert Settings in SAP Cloud logging to Receive Notifi...
entry.content:
Hi @Amemiya 

Thank you for your question.

Please note, the reason your CLS monitor only sends an alert the first time is because you’ve configured it as a Per Query Monitor. In this specific mode, the system evaluates the aggregated result and triggers an alert only once when the condition is met. It suppresses further alerts until the condition resets, even if the error persists.

To receive an alert every time the condition occurs, you should switch to a Per Document Monitor. This evaluates each log entry individually and can send alerts for every matching event.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Amount in Words in Indian Currency Format in Adobe Fo...
entry.content:
Hi @Achana_Bisoyi 

Thank you for the quick clarification.

Since you are working with the Public Cloud, you are right JavaScript or FormCalc scripts won’t run at runtime, as scripting is disabled in Adobe Forms Service for security reasons. That is why your Indian currency formatting works in preview but not during live execution.

A possible workaround could be:

  • You can use a custom field to manually input the amount in words.
  • Try to handle the formatting externally for example through SAP BTP/CPI and pass the result into the form.

Also, consider submitting a feature request via the SAP Influence Portal for native support of Indian currency formats.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: F2027: Manage Service Entry Sheets - PO reference dia...
entry.content:
Hi @veronika_skybova35

Thank you for detailing your requirement.

Based on the screenshots you provided, the “Add Purchase Order Items” screen which appears when you enter a PO number in the Service Entry Sheet app is populated by a non‑extensible CDS service. That means you cannot apply custom filtering to exclude delete, blocked items. This is because the list of PO items is not delivered as a key user or developer extensibility point. The CDS service is fixed, and there’s no means to intercept or modify it in BAS.

Although you found controller files like ListReportExtension.controller.js or SelectionDialogPO.fragment.xml in the BSP or frontend codebase, these are so called "behind the scenes" and not reachable via UI adaptation or key‑user projects. Considering the backend service itself is not made extensible, ther is no supported way to inject custom logic here.

Unfortunately, that means your desired filter criteria cannot be implemented in standard public-cloud customization. If you need this functionality, I suggest you register an enhancement request via the SAP Influence Portal is the best approach. That way SAP can evaluate adding extensibility in future releases.

However, you also have the possibility to explore workaround options such as: adding validation logic after item selection or using custom field extensions in the Service Entry Sheet itself.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Need to Change Scheduled Job Owner in SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
SAP provides a way to reassign ownership of scheduled jobs (like remote table replications or data flows) using the Data Integration Monitor. You do not need to stop or delete the jobs — you can take over ownership safely.

Below are the steps to reassign Ownership.

Open the Data Integration Monitor Go to your Space in SAP Datasphere and open the monitor for the relevant object (e.g., data flow or remote table).

Edit the Schedule. For remote tables, click Schedule Replication → Edit Schedule. For views or data flows, click Schedule → Edit Schedule

Assign to Me In the Edit Schedule window, click Assign to Me. Confirm the message and click OK.

Save the Schedule The Owner field will now show your user ID. The scheduling component will execute the task on your behalf.


You must have the SAP Datasphere Integrator role to perform this action.

You can follow SAP’s step-by-step guide here

entry.title: Re: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Belgium
entry.content:
You must have an active subscription to the PEPPOL Exchange Service for SAP DRC Cloud Edition. This service acts as your Access Point to the PEPPOL network. Without this, SAP DRC cannot send or receive documents via PEPPOL.
Yes, you must activate the “E-Invoicing (BE)” process in the Processes tab of SAP DRC. So go to SAP DRC dashboard, navigate to Processes, locate E-Invoicing (BE) and activate it. This enables the Belgium-specific logic and routing for PEPPOL invoices.

You need to register your company’s PEPPOL Participant ID in SAP DRC. So go to Master Data Management tab in SAP DRC, enter your Participant ID (e.g., GLN or VAT number). click Activate under Actions, status should change to “Send and Receive Enabled”. Also, ensure the same Participant ID is registered in your SAP Business Network account under Administration → Configuration → Configure External Network Identifiers.
In the Connection Management tab of SAP DRC, create a new connection, set System Type to Ariba or your source ERP and ensure the connection is active and mapped correctly

Check this SAP Help documentation for more information

entry.title: Re: SAP Service and Asset Manager (SSAM) - Existing User...
entry.content:
Hi @yashoratna 

Thanks for your question.

What you're observing in SAP Service and Asset Manager is expected behaviour when updating user statuses via the Mobile Status Setting in the Mobile Application Integration Framework.

When a mobile status like HOLD is mapped to a user status, the app overwrites the entire user status field group, which results in removal of previously set statuses such as 3000 or 5100. This is due to how user status management works in SAP. It does not support additive logic out of the box in this context.

To enable you retain existing user statuses when applying new ones via the mobile app, you will need to implement the following:

  • A custom BADI or enhancement in the backend for example BADI_EAM_EXIT_STATUS. This will capture and merges the existing and new statuses, rather than replacing them.
  • Alternatively, you can consider grouping related user statuses under the same status profile with the logic that allows multiple status to coexist. This however depends on your desired business rules.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Step-by-Step Implementation Guide: SAP DRC Cash Flow Statements with Video Tutorials
entry.content:
Cash flow statements are one of the three fundamental financial statements that every business must prepare, alongside the income statement and balance sheet. While the income statement shows profitability and the balance sheet displays financial position, the cash flow statement reveals the actual cash movements in and out of your business. Understanding how to prepare and interpret cash flow statements—and choosing between the direct and indirect methods—is crucial for effective financial management.

This comprehensive guide includes detailed video tutorials to walk you through every aspect of implementing SAP DRC-based cash flow statements, from initial setup to advanced configuration and real-world examples.

 

1. What is a Cash Flow Statement?

A cash flow statement tracks the actual cash receipts and payments during a specific period, categorized into three main activities:

  • Operating Activities: Cash flows from core business operations
  • Investing Activities: Cash flows from buying/selling long-term assets
  • Financing Activities: Cash flows from debt, equity, and dividend transactions

The statement answers a critical question: "Where did our cash come from, and where did it go?"

1.1 The Two Methods: Direct vs. Indirect

The accounting standards allow two approaches for presenting the operating activities section of the cash flow statement:

The Indirect Method

The indirect method starts with net income and adjusts for non-cash items and changes in working capital to arrive at operating cash flow.

Typical Indirect Method Structure:

Net Income                            $100,000
Adjustments:
  Depreciation                        $20,000
  Increase in Accounts Receivable     ($15,000)
  Decrease in Inventory               $10,000
  Increase in Accounts Payable        $8,000
Net Cash from Operating Activities    $123,000

Advantages of Indirect Method:

  • Easier to prepare from existing financial statements
  • Less expensive to implement
  • Shows the relationship between net income and cash flow

Disadvantages:

  • Doesn't show actual cash receipts and payments
  • Less useful for cash flow forecasting
  • More difficult for users to understand actual cash movements

The Direct Method

The direct method reports actual cash receipts and payments from operating activities, showing gross cash flows.

Typical Direct Method Structure:

Cash Receipts:
  From customers                      $500,000
  From interest and dividends         $5,000
Cash Payments:
  To suppliers                        ($200,000)
  To employees                        ($150,000)
  For interest                        ($10,000)
  For taxes                           ($22,000)
Net Cash from Operating Activities    $123,000

Advantages of Direct Method:

  • Shows actual cash transactions
  • More intuitive and easier to understand
  • Better for cash flow forecasting

Disadvantages:

  • More expensive and complex to implement
  • Requires detailed tracking of cash receipts and payments

1.2 The Challenge: Implementing the Direct Method

While the direct method provides superior information, most companies avoid it due to implementation challenges. The main obstacle is that traditional accounting systems record transactions by account, not by cash flow categories. To prepare a direct method cash flow statement, you need to:

  1. Identify cash transactions among all recorded transactions
  2. Classify each cash flow into the appropriate category
  3. Match cash receipts and payments to understand the complete cash flow picture

This is where offsetting account determination becomes invaluable.

1.3 How Offsetting Account Determination Enables Direct Method Cash Flow

Offsetting account determination is a sophisticated process that automatically pairs each debit posting with exactly one credit posting in your accounting documents. Here's how it works and why it's crucial for direct method cash flow statements:

The Pairing Process

When you post a transaction, the system automatically:

  1. Identifies offsetting accounts for each G/L account line item
  2. Creates paired relationships between debits and credits
  3. Stores the pairing information for reporting purposes

Practical Example: Supplier Invoice

Consider a supplier invoice posting:

Before Offsetting Account Determination:

Account                          Debit    Credit
Goods Receipt/Invoice Receipt    $1,000    -
Deferred Tax                     $180      -
Accounts Payable                 -         $1,180

After Offsetting Account Determination:

Pairing 1:
Goods Receipt/Invoice Receipt    $1,000    -
Accounts Payable                 -         $1,000

Pairing 2:
Deferred Tax                     $180      -
Accounts Payable                 -         $180

This pairing process provides several advantages:

  1. Automatic Cash Flow Classification: Each cash payment can be automatically classified based on its offsetting account
  2. Detailed Transaction Tracking: You can trace exactly what each cash flow represents
  3. Accurate Reporting: Eliminates guesswork in categorizing cash flows
  4. Audit Trail: Provides clear documentation of cash flow sources and uses

 

2. Getting Started with SAP DRC Cash Flow Statements

The video tutorials that follow are designed to provide hands-on guidance for both technical implementers and business users. Each tutorial builds upon the previous one, creating a complete learning path that ensures successful implementation and adoption of the solution. All videos can also be accessed through this playlist: Step-by-Step Implementing SAP DRC Cash Flow Statements 

What You'll Gain from This Implementation Guide

By following this step-by-step approach, you'll be able to:

  • Understand the complete cash flow statement landscape and choose the right method for your organization
  • Configure both direct and indirect methods with proper SAP DRC framework setup
  • Implement advanced features like offsetting account determination for superior cash flow visibility
  • Handle real-world scenarios with practical examples and troubleshooting guidance

2.1 Video Tutorial 1: Understanding Cash Flow Statements

Video Link: https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_pnx4sufg

This introductory video provides a comprehensive overview of cash flow statements and their importance in financial reporting.

Key Topics Covered:

  • Background and Context: Why cash flow statements matter for businesses
  • Regulatory Requirements: How different countries mandate cash flow reporting
  • Two Methods Explained: Direct vs. Indirect method differences
  • SAP Solution Overview: How SAP S/4HANA supports both methods

 

2.2 Video Tutorial 2: How to Use SAP DRC Cash Flow Statement

Video Link: https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_mycrc7yw

This comprehensive tutorial demonstrates the practical steps for using the SAP DRC cash flow statement solution in your daily operations, including advanced analytical features.

Key Features Demonstrated:

  • Report Navigation: Finding cash flow statements in the Run Statutory Report app
  • Filter Configuration: Setting up proper filters for reporting status, entity, and period
  • Report Generation: Step-by-step process for creating new cash flow statements
  • File Management: Understanding generated PDF and ALV table views

 

2.3 Video Tutorial 3: Configure Statutory Reporting Framework

Video Link: https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_y50w1v3l

This configuration tutorial covers the essential setup steps for the statutory reporting framework that forms the foundation of the SAP DRC cash flow solution.

Configuration Overview:

  • Report Entity Definition: Setting up country-specific entities
  • Report Categories: Configuring direct and indirect method categories
  • Periodicity Parameters: Defining reporting frequency and due dates
  • Organization Unit Assignment: Mapping company codes to reporting entities

 

2.4 Video Tutorial 4: Setting Up Direct Method Cash Flow Statements

Video Link: https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_92z3ujqp

This detailed configuration tutorial covers all aspects of setting up the direct method cash flow statement, including the essential offsetting account determination functionality.

Configuration Overview:

1. Direct Method Configuration

  • Cash Flow Statement Version: Defining reporting structure and hierarchy
  • Account Assignment: Configuring cash, offsetting, and invoice accounts
  • Item Types and Modes: Understanding calculation attributes
  • Limiting Parameters: Setting up transaction type filters

2. Offsetting Account Determination

  • Version Definition: Creating determination rules for document splitting
  • Preferred Pairs: Setting up priority account combinations
  • Forbidden Pairs: Preventing inappropriate account pairings
  • Activation Process: Enabling the solution for specific document types

 

2.5 Video Tutorial 5: Configure Indirect Method Cash Flow Statement

Video Link: https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_3q5sgz07

This configuration tutorial covers the setup for indirect method cash flow statements, which is simpler than direct method but still requires proper configuration.

Configuration Overview:

  • Separate Version ID: Creating dedicated indirect method versions
  • Balance-Based Items: Configuring GL balance calculations

 

2.6 Video Tutorial 6: Real-World Examples - Sample Business Cases

Video Link: https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_x7zjnu6g

This practical tutorial demonstrates three common business scenarios and how the SAP DRC solution handles each case automatically.

Sample Case 1: Payment for Purchase

  • Outgoing payment to supplier
  • AP invoice with expense classification
  • Clearing relationship between payment and invoice

Sample Case 2: Bank in Transit

  • Bank statement posting with bank in transit
  • Customer payment clearing through transit account
  • Customer invoice with revenue recognition

Sample Case 3: Goods Receipt Account (GR/IR)

  • Purchase order with goods receipt and invoice receipt
  • GR/IR account usage in purchasing process
  • Complex clearing relationships

 

3. Conclusion

SAP DRC cash flow statements provide powerful financial reporting capabilities for organizations worldwide. The direct method offers superior cash flow visibility through offsetting account determination, while the indirect method provides a simpler implementation path.

Next Steps:

  1. Check SAP Help Portal for your country's specific DRC Reports.
  2. Download the implementation guide slides used in the videos.
  3. Join the SAP DRC Community for ongoing support and updates.

entry.title: Re: What is the storage capacity of SAP Signavio process...
entry.content:
Hello @Victorcardona 

Thank you for your question.

For SAP Signavio Process Governance, the storage quota is 10 MB per license (across all license types such as Enterprise, Enterprise Plus, Collaboration Hub, etc.). You can purchase additional storage up to a maximum of 2048 MB per workspace if required

Please note that this quota covers only externally uploaded documents e.g., PDF’s and does not include process models or diagrams, which are stored elsewhere in the system

You can view your current usage and total capacity in the application under Explorer → Import/Export → Upload documents/pictures.

If your organization needs additional capacity, you can request more storage blocks through your SAP account representative.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Handling inventory updates from EWM to S/4HANA Cloud...
entry.content:
Yes — SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) is currently the recommended and most widely adopted workaround for enabling back-synchronization from decentralized EWM to S/4HANA Cloud. Here's how and why:

  1. S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition only supports whitelisted APIs (OData, SOAP) — no direct RFC or IDoc connections.
  2. EWM on Private Cloud can publish events or trigger outbound messages (IDocs, BAPIs).
  3. CPI acts as the middleware, transforming and routing these messages to S/4HANA Cloud APIs.

Some of the Best Practices for CPI-Based Back-Synchronization are

Event-Driven Architecture - Use SAP Event Mesh or EWM’s change pointers to trigger CPI flows. Example EWM posts a cycle count → triggers event → CPI calls S/4HANA Cloud Inventory API

Use standard APIs like:

 

  • /API_OUTBOUND_DELIVERY_SRV for delivery updates
  • /API_PHYSINV_DOC_SRV for inventory adjustments
  • /API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV for goods movement confirmations

Use CPI’s graphical mapping tools to convert EWM IDoc/XML formats to S/4HANA Cloud OData payloads. Ensure proper authentication (OAuth or certificates) and endpoint configuration.

Enable CPI monitoring dashboards. Use SAP Application Interface Framework (AIF) in EWM for outbound message tracking. Implement retry logic and alerts for failed syncs.

SAP has not yet committed to supporting these warehouse-driven updates in standard 7L1 integration. However, partners and customers are actively lobbying for:

  • Extended API coverage
  • Standard CPI content packages
  • Improved event handling in S/4HANA Cloud

You can track roadmap updates via the SAP Roadmap Explorer.

entry.title: Re: Need to Change Scheduled Job Owner in SAP Datasphere
entry.content:
In order to take the ownership of a Replication Flow is

  • you must have the SAP Datasphere Integrator role. Optionally, also have Viewer or Modeler role for access to the relevant objects.
  • Open Data Integration Monitor, navigate to your Space in SAP Datasphere. Open the Data Integration Monitor for the Replication Flow.
  • Locate the Replication Flow, find the scheduled Replication Flow you want to take over. Click on the flow to open its details.
  • Edit the Schedule, click Schedule Replication → Edit Schedule.
  • Assign to Me, in the Edit Schedule window, click Assign to Me.
  • Confirm the message and click OK.
  • Save the Schedule, the Owner field will now show your user ID. The job will continue running under your ownership without disruption.

entry.title: Person Responsible in Lease contract management
entry.content:
Recently we have deleted a user which was entered in Person Responsible in Contract. We had to manually change person responsible one by one for 300 contracts, since the user id dont exist anymore.

  1. Is there any option to mass change the field?
  2. In future if a user leaves organization, we need to remove the user? In this case how can we deal with it?

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Person Responsible in Lease contract management
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

Thank you for your question!

When the business user assigned as 'Person Responsible' to Real Estate/Lease contracts is deleted from the system, the field needs to be updated to an active user for all contracts where this business user was assigned.
While manually updating the field on all impacted contracts is a possibility, but as you have also highlighted it can be a very time consuming and tedious process.

Fortunately there are a number of APIs available in Contract and Lease Management which alleviate the workload on this and enables mass updating of this field on all contracts easily.

You can read more about the relevant API in the SAP Help Portal article (in the 'Real Estate Contract' section you can find the field 'Responsible' which is the one you'll need in this particular case, as well as there are a number of 'Example Requests' available to learn more about how to put the requests together).
You can also refer to the technical documentation available via the SAP Business Accelerator Hub where further technical details are available and the page also gives an opportunity to try out the API's many functionalities.

entry.title: SAP Build Process Automation: Process Triggers: A Step-by-Step Demo on Invoice Validation Approval
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Welcome back to our SAP Build Process Automation series! In this second blog, we'll dive deep into one of the most crucial aspects of process automation: how to trigger your business processes. Understanding the various trigger mechanisms is essential for building robust, automated workflows that can respond to different business scenarios.

Every business process follows a simple flow: it starts with a trigger, executes a series of activities, and ends with a desired outcome. The question is: how do we initiate these processes effectively? Today, we'll explore the four primary ways to trigger processes in SAP Build Process Automation with complete step-by-step instructions.

API Triggers

Let's walk through a comprehensive implementation of API triggers using our Sales Order Management example.

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have:

  1. Access to SAP Build Process Automation
  2. A working process (we'll use the vendor invoice validation approval process project from previous episodes)
  3. Any Rest Client software (web or desktop version)
  4. BTP Cockpit access for service key retrieval - trial cockpit

Step-by-Step Implementation 

Phase 1: Project Setup and Preparation 

Step 1: Create a Copy of Your Existing Project from previous blog

  1. Navigate to SAP Build Lobby
  2. Locate your existing project (e.g., "Invoice Validation Approval Process Form")
  3. Select the project by clicking on it
  4. Click "Save As" to create a copy
  5. Enter new project details: 
    1. Project Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Trigger 
    2. Description: A invoice validation and approval process trigger
  6. Click "Save" to create the new project   

Step 2: Access and Prepare the Process

  1. Open the newly created project
  2. Navigate to the process section
  3. You should see:
    • Four forms
    • One process
    •  Existing form trigger (Invoice Validation Approval Process Form)

Phase 2: Removing Existing Process and Adding API Trigger

Step 3: Remove the Existing Form Process

  1. Click on the existing form process (Invoice Validation Approval Process Form)
  2. Click "Remove" to delete the form
  3. You'll now see a block asking "How do you want to start your process?"
  4. Click "Add a trigger"

Step 4: Explore Available Trigger Options You'll see four trigger options:

  1. Submit a form: Creates/uses existing forms
  2. API trigger: For external system integration
  3. Event trigger: For event-driven processes
  4. Schedule trigger: For time-based execution

Step 5: Create the API Trigger

  1. Click on "API Trigger"
  2. Save the process (mandatory before creating API trigger)
    • Click the Save button
  3. Configure API Trigger Details: 
    • Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Trigger 
    • Identifier: [Auto-generated - do not modify]
  4. Click "Create"
  5. You'll see a success message: "API trigger created successfully"   

Phase 3: Understanding API Trigger Configuration 

Step 6: Examine API Trigger Properties

  1. Click on the API trigger you just created
  2. Review Output Fields:
  • These are automatically synchronized from process inputs
  • Fields include: Vendor Name, Invoice Number, Invoice Date, Vendor Email, Invoice Amount, Due Date
  • These represent the data structure your API will receive

Step 7: Check Process Variables Synchronization

  1. Click anywhere in the process canvas
  2. Navigate to Variables tab
  3. Select "Process Inputs"
  4. Verify synchronization:
    • API trigger outputs = Process inputs
    • This ensures seamless data flow

Step 8: Review API Configuration Details

  1. Click on the API trigger
  2. Go to "Configuration" tab
  3. Note the important details:
    • Field Identifiers: Use these in JSON (not display names)
    • Mandatory Fields: All fields shown are required
    • Data Types: Note numeric vs. string vs. date formats

Phase 4: Project Release and Deployment 

Step 9: Release the Project

  1. Save all changes
  2. Click "Release" button in the top toolbar
  3. Confirm the release when prompted
  4. Wait for successful release message

Step 10: Deploy the Project

  1. Click "Deploy" button (appears after release)
  2. Select target environment (typically "Public Environment")
  3. Confirm deployment
  4. Wait for deployment completion
  5. Note the deployment success message

Phase 5: Accessing Deployment Information 

Step 11: Navigate to Control Tower

  1. Go to SAP Build Lobby home
  2. Click on "Control Tower"
  3. Navigate to "Tenant Configuration"
  4. Click on "Environments"
  5. Select "Public Environment" (or your deployment target)

Step 12: Locate Your Deployed Project

  1. Find your project: "Vendor Invoice Validation Approval Process Triggers"
  2. Click on the project name
  3. Navigate to "Triggers" tab
  4. Locate: "Vendor Invoice Approval API Trigger"

Step 13: Get API Endpoint Information

  1. Click on "View Trigger"
  2. Copy the API URL - you'll need this for Rest Client
  3. Review the Payload Definition - this shows the exact JSON structure required

Example URL Structure:  https://[Tenant-URL] /workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances

Example Payload Structure JSON: 

{  
"definitionId": "[auto-generated-id]", 
"context": {  
"Vendor Name": "string",  
"invoiceNumber": "number",  
"invoiceDate": "date", 
"vendorEmail": "string", 
"invoiceAmount": "number",  
"dueDate": "date"  
} 
} 

Phase 6: BTP Service Key Configuration 

Step 14: Access BTP Cockpit

  1. Open BTP Cockpit in a new tab
  2. Navigate to your subaccount
  3. Go to "Instances and Subscriptions"
  4. Locate "SAP Build Process Automation"

Step 15: Retrieve Service Key Details

  1. Click on "SAP Build Process Automation" service
  2. Navigate to "Service Keys" tab
  3. Click on existing service key (or create one if none exists)
  4. Copy the following values: 
{  
"endpoints": {    
"api": "[API_ENDPOINT]"  
},  
"uaa": {    
"clientid ": "[CLIENT_ID]",    
"clientsecret": "[CLIENT_SECRET]",    
"url": "[TOKEN_URL]"  
} 
}

Phase 7: Rest Client Configuration and Testing 

Step 16: Configure OAuth 2.0 Authentication

  1. Go to "Authorization" tab
  2. Select "OAuth 2.0" from dropdown
  3. Configure OAuth settings:
    • Token Name: SAP Build Token (or any name)
    • Grant Type: Client Credentials
    • Access Token URL: [TOKEN_URL from service key]
    • Client ID: [CLIENT_ID from service key]
    • Client Secret: [CLIENT_SECRET from service key]

Step 17: Generate Access Token

  1. Click "Get New Access Token"
  2. Wait for token generation
  3. Click "Use Token" when generated
  4. Verify: You should see "Authentication complete" message

Step 18: Configure Request Body

  1. Go to "Body" tab
  2. Select "raw"
  3. Select "JSON" from dropdown
  4. Enter the payload: 
{
"definitionId": "[DEFINITION_ID_from_step_13]",
"context": {  
"vendorName": "ABCD",
"invoiceNumber": 1234,
"invoiceDate": "2025-08-05",
"vendorEmail": "abcd@test.com",
"invoiceAmount": 1000,
"dueDate": "2025-08-08" 
}
}

Step 19: Execute the API Call

  1. Click "Send"
  2. Expected Response:     
{
  "status": "201 Created",
  "message": "New resource was created successfully"
}

Phase 8: Process Monitoring and Verification 
Step 21: Monitor Process Instance

  1. Return to SAP Build Lobby
  2. Navigate to "Monitoring"
  3. Click "Process and Workflow Instances"
  4. Locate your new process instance:
    • Status: Running
    • Instance ID: [Auto-generated]
    • Started by: API Trigger

Step 22: Review Process Data

  1. Click on the process instance
  2. Review "Process Details":
    • Vendor Name: ABCD
    • Invoice Number: 1234
    • Invoice Amount: 1000
    • Vendor Email: abcd@test.com
    • Due Date: 2024-08-08

    3. Check process flow: Should be waiting for approval

Phase 9: Complete the Approval Workflow 

Step 23: Access Manager Inbox

  1. Navigate to "My Inbox" app
  2. Login as Finance Clerk
  3. Locate the approval task:
    • Title: Vendor Name [ABCD]
    • Status: Open
    • All order details visible

Step 24: Process the Approval

  1. Click on the task
  2. Review order details:
    • Vendor Name: ABCD
    • Invoice Amount: 1000
    • Invoice Email: abcd@test.com
    • Due Date: 2024-08-08
    • Invoice Number - 1234
    • Invoice Date - 2024-08-05
  3. Add approval comment:
  4. Click "Approve"
  5. Confirm: "Task has been processed successfully"

Step 25: Handle Vendor Invoice Representative Notification

  1. Switch to Finance Manager role
  2. Check "My Inbox"
  3. Locate notification: "Vendor Invoice form approved successfully"
  4. Click on notification
  5. Review confirmation details
  6. Click "Submit"

Step 26: Verify Process Completion

  1. Return to "Process and Workflow Instances"
  2. Refresh the page
  3. Check your process instance:
    • Status: Completed
    • All approval messages visible
    • Complete process flow executed  

Conclusion

In this blog, we walked through the complete lifecycle of implementing API triggers in SAP Build Process Automation using a real-world scenario of vendor invoice validation and approval. From project setup to deployment, from obtaining service keys to testing API calls with Rest Client, we demonstrated how API triggers enable seamless integration between external systems and your automated workflows.

This approach empowers businesses to respond programmatically to events, ensuring faster and more scalable process initiation. Whether you're integrating SAP Build with external applications, triggering approvals based on backend systems, or building custom UI workflows, API triggers provide the flexibility and control needed for robust automation.

entry.title: Re: SAP CRM popup when leaving transaction launcher
entry.content:
Hi @rpetrulis 

You're right. The "Possible data loss continue?" popup is a standard safeguard in SAP CRM when exiting WebGUI-based transaction launchers (BOR/FOP). Unfortunately, this behaviour cannot be disabled via standard configuration, and the DATALOSS flag in table CRMC_IC_LTX_URL only applies to URL-based launchers.

Some workaround methods like suppressing ON_BEFORE_WA_CONTENT_CHANGE via DO_CLEANUP_CONTEXT exist but are unsupported custom solutions. It is also unsupported and required custom development outside standard SAP maintenance scope. It is not recommended in productive systems.

I hope this helps provide clarity for your customer. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: CC cost allocation will be done for the costs remaini...
entry.content:
The standard cost center allocation cycle in S/4HANA Cloud does not automatically exclude secondary cost postings (e.g., timesheet transfers to WBS elements). It simply allocates the total posted cost on the cost center, including both primary and secondary costs; unless explicitly configured otherwise.

This behavior is due to no default filtering of cost types (primary vs. secondary) in allocation cycles and lack of automatic netting logic to subtract already transferred costs.

To allocate only the net cost (i.e., total cost minus timesheet transfers), you can apply one of the following approaches:

  • Use the “Manage Allocations” app to configure your allocation cycle, include only primary cost elements in the allocation segment, exclude secondary cost elements used for timesheet transfers (e.g., activity allocation). This ensures that only the unallocated portion of the cost center is distributed. Importantly, use the “Sender Cost Element Group” field to define which cost elements are included.
  • If you need more granular control, post timesheet costs using SKFs to track transferred quantities, use SKFs in allocation cycles to proportionally allocate remaining costs. This method allows dynamic allocation based on actual usage.
  • Create a custom CDS view that calculates total cost center cost, minus secondary postings to WBS and resulting net cost

Use this view to validate or drive manual allocations if automation isn't feasible.

entry.title: Re: HANA SDA Remote Source - Authorization
entry.content:
Hi @Martin2 

Thank you for your question.

The syntax error you're getting is likely due to either:

  • Incorrect use of quotes or case in the remote source name.
  • Use of WITH GRANT OPTION without sufficient privileges.
  • Not being the owner of the remote source.

I suggest you try this version:

GRANT ALTER ON REMOTE SOURCE XYZ TO ROLE "REMOTE_SOURCE_ALTER";

Please make sure you're executing it as the user who created the remote source or has the necessary admin rights.

I hope this helps provide clarity for your customer. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Chris

entry.title: Re: InterCompany Journal Entry Voucher Web service error
entry.content:
Hello,

In general web services are meant to be used with Technical user maintained in the communication arrangement.

In some cases like for example Supplier invoice ByDesign have a Import from Excel feature. This Import from excel uses the same Web service operation and since Import from Excel can be done only by a business user these web services are allowed to use technical users as well as business users.

In case of intercompany JEV, this service does not allow the use of Business user and hence to create the Intercompany JEV, you must use Technical User defined in the communication arrangement.

Thanks,
Harshal

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA EHS Risk Assessment - Delivery of List REACH-...
entry.content:
Hello @duc_minh 

Thank you for your question.

I will walk through the details available on this topic. Let us look at the following:

Current State of Regulatory List Delivery

  • SAP now provides regulatory substance lists via the Product Compliance solution, not via the outdated EH&S‑HS component or manual notes.
  • Please note, these lists including REACH SVHC, RoHS, REACH Annex XIV are included in the “standard regulatory content” of SAP Product Compliance and are delivered with each S/4HANA on‑premise, private cloud, or public cloud release. They are embedded and cannot be installed through notes in newer releases.

What it means for your EHS‑HS Environment

For S/4HANA 2023 and beyond, you should use the SAP Product and REACH Compliance solution, do not rely on the older EH&S‑HS notes.

The work set for regulatory lists in Product Compliance includes REACH‑SVHC, RoHS, Annex XIV, and more. You can manage content updates through the Compliance Workbench.

If you still operate in legacy EHS‑Workplace Safety without full Product Compliance, you’ll need to transition to Product Compliance to continue receiving up-to-date list content.

To summarize that content for you:

As of S/4HANA 2023, the regulatory lists REACH-SVHC, RoHS, and REACH-Annex XIV are no longer delivered via SAP Notes like 2427915 or 2116459. Instead, they are now part of the standard regulatory content in SAP Product Compliance.

SAP continues to maintain and update these lists, but they are embedded in the system and managed through the Product Compliance Workbench, not via manual updates.

I hope this helps provide clarity for your customer. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP CI Just Started Talking to AI : Introducing the new AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Ever wished your iFlow could talk to ChatGPT?
Now it can! With SAP’s new AI Adapter, your integrations can tap into the power of Large Language Models like OpenAI's GPT, making your processes smarter and more self-sufficient.

SAP has introduced a game-changing capability in its Integration Suite—the AI Adapter. Whether you're connecting to SAP AI Core via the GenAI Hub or tapping into OpenAI through REST APIs, this adapter allows your integration flows to think, respond, and act using the power of generative AI.

With the AI Adapter, integration is no longer just about connectivity—it’s about cognitive capability. You’re not simply passing data; you’re enabling your iFlows to understand, reason, and generate intelligent output in real-time.

It unlocks a new era of integration where:
  • Decisions are dynamic
  • Responses are contextual
  • Workflows are augmented with AI-driven intelligence

Your iFlow is no longer silent. It can now ask, interpret, and respond—like a real assistant embedded within your process.

From streamlining operations to enriching business workflows with human-like intelligence, the AI Adapter is a leap toward next-gen, AI-powered integration landscapes.

Key Features of the AI Adapter in SAP Integration Suite

The AI Adapter extends the power of SAP Integration Suite by enabling seamless integration with generative AI providers. It comes in two flexible variants and supports a wide range of intelligent capabilities:

Two Powerful Variants
  • AICore-GenAIHub: Connects directly to SAP AI Core’s orchestration services to consume multiple GenAI models using a unified configuration and deployment setup.
  • Custom-OpenAI-REST: Connects to OpenAI’s public APIs, enabling integration with advanced LLMs (like ChatGPT) for tasks like text generation, classification, and more.
Secure Authentication Options
  • OAuth2 Client Credentials for the AICore-GenAIHub variant.
  • API Key Alias (Secure Parameter) support for the Custom-OpenAI-REST variant.
Unified API Design
  • The AICore-GenAIHub variant uses a harmonized API, allowing you to switch between different foundational models without changing client code.
Custom-OpenAI-REST Capabilities
  • Full access to OpenAI’s powerful endpoints including Chat Completions, Platform metadata, Rich AI-generated responses and more
Dual Configuration Modes
  • Basic Mode: Simplified setup for common use cases and supported endpoints.
  • Advanced Mode: Full control for experienced developers to call any API endpoint with custom headers, payloads, and processing logic.

There are countless possibilities when it comes to leveraging the AI Adapter in SAP Integration Suite—whether it’s intelligent document processing, language translation, content generation, or decision support. But in this blog, we’re focusing on a simple yet powerful scenario that highlights intelligent automation in action.

Scenario: Generative AI-Augmented Error Handling

In this walkthrough, we’ll use the Custom-OpenAI-REST variant of the AI Adapter to build an iFlow that:

  1. Detects a failed message in your integration flow

  2. Sends the error details to OpenAI’s GPT model via the AI Adapter

  3. Receives a context-aware resolution from the AI model

  4. Creates a Jira ticket automatically with the AI-suggested resolution

Now your iFlow doesn’t just log the error—it understands it, reacts to it, and initiates action.

Setting Up Your OpenAI Account and creation of API Key

To integrate OpenAI with SAP Integration Suite using the Custom-OpenAI-REST variant of the AI Adapter, you'll need an OpenAI account and an API key. Here's how to get started:

Create/Open Your OpenAI Account

  1. Go to https://platform.openai.com

  2. Click Sign up / Log in

3. Setup your account / Create Organization

4. Set a API key name and Project name

 

5. Copy and securely store the API key (Caution: This key is shown only once—make sure to save it)

You can check all the configurations by clicking on your profile at the Top right.

Activate Billing on Your OpenAI Account (Mandatory for API Access)

Having an OpenAI account and API key is not enough. You must have an active billing setup.  Earlier, OpenAI offered free trial credits ($5 to $18) to new accounts.
But as of 2024, trial credits are no longer guaranteed, especially for accounts from certain regions (like India).

So unless you’re explicitly granted trial usage, the default quota is $0 — and any API call will fail unless billing is enabled.

How to Set Up Billing for OpenAI API Access

  • Go to: https://platform.openai.com/account/billing/payment-methods

  • Click "Add payment method", and enter your debit/credit card details.

  • Once the card is added, you are automatically enrolled into a pay-as-you-go plan.

If your account has no active quota, you’ll see errors like:

Reason: Invoke api failed, urlPath:https://api.openai.com/v1/chat/completions status:429 response: Too Many Requests
errorEntity:{
"error": {
"message": "You exceeded your current quota, please check your plan and billing details. For more information on this error, read the docs: https://platform.openai.com/docs/guides/error-codes/api-errors.",
"type": "insufficient_quota",
"param": null,
"code": "insufficient_quota"
}
}

All set on OpenAI end, Now lets hop on to our very own SAP Cloud Integration.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

SAP Cloud Integration:

For this demonstration, I’ve created an iFlow that uses the Google Pub/Sub Adapter with intentionally incorrect KeyPair/Certificate, triggering a failure during message processing. This failure is caught by the Exception Subprocess, where we harness the power of the AI Adapter to analyze the error and fetch a resolution using AI.

The returned resolution is then added as an attachment to the MPL (Message Processing Log) for traceability. Additionally, based on an external parameter, we can optionally trigger the creation of a Jira ticket containing the AI-suggested fix.

This blog will cover only the Exception Sub Process, keeping the spotlight on error handling within integration flows.

AI Adapter : Use a Request-Reply and pick AI adapter of variant Custom-OpenAI-REST from the dropdown.

 

 

Connection Tab:

ParameterDescription
AddressSpecify the OpenAI Address.
Example: https://api.openai.com
API Key Alias

Specify the API Key alias. Create a Secure Parameter in the security artifact to store the API Key that we created in OpenAI Account. 

Caution: The value of API Key Alias must be a combination of
<Bearer > and {API Key provided by OpenAPI}.

Reuse ConnectionEnable to reuse the connection.
Connection Timeout (in
ms)		Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for the connection to be established.
Response Timeout (in ms)Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for a response message.

Processing Tab:

ParameterDescription
Configuration TypeSelect the required configuration type:
• Basic to use the dropdowns and parameter text fields
• Advanced to specify the relative URL
Category"Chat Completions" : The use case is about sending a prompt to the model and get the response
Entity"Chat Completion"
Operation"Create a model response for the given chat conversation"
Request Payload
Source		- "UI Configurable" provides user friendly fields to create the payload
automatically.
- "Exchange Body" allows you to specify required structure and
values
ModelYou can select the model which is available to use for your openAI account. Make a GET call to this endpoint https://api.openai.com/v1/models to know the available models for your account
Prompt

Using UI Configurable in this use case, this field gets visible where we need to enter the prompt that goes as a request to the AI model.

Prompt : Suggest a possible solutions for the error : "${property.CamelExceptionCaught}" in 200 words plain text format. Do not include any special characters, double quotes and line breaks.

Request HeadersEnter a list of custom headers, separated by a pipe (|), to be sent to the target system
Response HeadersEnter a list of headers, separated by a pipe (|), coming from the target system's response to be received in the message

JSON to XML Converter : AI model returns the response in JSON format, it contains various fields, but our focus is on the "content" field which has the result. Its easier to extract the field from a XML file rather than a JSON. Hence there is a usage of JSON to XML Converter.

Response from AI model:

 

Content Modifier : "Extract Resolution" is used to extract "content" field from the XML.

Groovy Script : LogAttachment We will log the resolution that we received from AI model as an attachment in the Message processing logs:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;

def Message processData(Message message) 
{
    def body = message.getBody(String)
    def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
    def resolution = message.getProperty("resolution") as String
    if(messageLog != null)
    {
    messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("Resolution", resolution, "text/plain");
    }
    return message;
}

Process Call : "Call Jira", this process call executes the Call Jira local integration process. This is an optional configuration based on the External Parameter "CreateJiraCard", this is execute only when its value is "YES".

Jira Integration configuration is NOT covered in this blog, Check out the below blog for details related to Jira Integration.

Jira Adapter for SAP Integration Suite 

Demo:

Misconfiguration in GooglePubSub Adapter:

Keystore : No keypair found for alias "googlekey123"

Deploying the flow: Lets see how AI helps us with the resolution here.

MPL logs:

Attachment "Resolution": Response from AI model can be seen in this attachment

Response from AI: 

One possible solution for the error "org.apache.camel.CamelException: No key pair found for Private Key Alias: googlekey123" is to ensure that the private key with the specified alias "googlekey123" is correctly added to the keystore or key repository being used by the application.

First, you should confirm that the private key with the alias "googlekey123" exists in the keystore or key repository. If it does not exist, you may need to generate a new key pair with the correct alias and add it to the keystore.

Next, verify that the keystore or key repository configuration in the application matches the location and password of the keystore where the private key is stored. Make sure that the application has the necessary permissions to access the keystore.

You may also need to restart the application to ensure that the changes in the keystore or key repository configuration take effect.

If the issue persists, double-check the spelling of the alias "googlekey123" and verify that it is being referenced correctly in the application code.

By following these steps, you should be able to resolve the error and successfully retrieve the private key with the alias "googlekey123" in your application.

The Integration also created a JIRA ticket as shown below:

Pretty cool, right? The AI instantly analyzed the error and answered with remarkably accurate resolution—all within seconds. No manual debugging, no digging through logs—just a smart, contextual answer delivered right when you need it.

This is where traditional error handling ends and intelligent integration begins.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Conclusion: From Automation to Intelligence—This Is Just the Start

With the AI Adapter, your iFlows are no longer static pipelines—they become intelligent systems that can analyze, respond, and act with precision. From generating real-time resolutions to automatically logging tickets in Jira, and even notifying teams via email or chat platforms like Microsoft Teams—the potential is endless.

It’s a a blueprint for building truly smart integration scenarios that adapt, learn, and evolve with your business needs.

We now stand at the edge of next-generation integration design, where AI is not a bolt-on, but a native capability within your flow logic.

The question is no longer what can you automate?
It’s how far can you let your integrations think for you?

The future of integration is here—and it’s intelligent!!

References: AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite

Up next : Curious about how the GenAI Hub variant of SAP AI Core fits into enterprise scenarios? The next blog has you covered — with an exciting new use case!

Hope this helps!

Cheers,

Punith Oswal

entry.title: Re: Enter a value for field REPRF
entry.content:
Hi,
It is generally related to LFM1-REPRF (Accounting Clerk) field being required in the supplier master. In my case i didn't had any purchasing data yet got the error. 
This was due to MDG model was enforcing field requirements based on Account Group configuration in SPRO or the Data Model (e.g., BP, Supplier).
 
Check if REPRF is required as per Account Group in MDG
This defines required fields per account group in the backend:
 
SPRO Path:
SPRO → SAP Reference IMG → Financial Accounting → Accounts Receivable and Accounts Payable → Vendor Accounts → Master Data → Preparations for Creating Vendor Master Data → Define Account Groups with Screen Layout (Vendors)
Select the Account Group you’re using (e.g., Z001).
 
Check the Field Status under the “Vendor: Purchasing Data” section.
 
Look for Field REPRF (Accounting Clerk).
 
If it's set to "Required", this is likely causing the issue.

entry.title: Re: Username SAP Insights
entry.content:
Hello @CP_PL 

Thanks for raising this.

Based on SAP documentations, it appears that SAP Insights currently does not offer a standard setting to hide usernames in transaction or activity details and cannot be suppressed via standard configuration. The display you are seeing is likely the default behaviour after reinstallation. Please note that it is not controlled by a data protection toggle.

Please note, if this poses a data protection concern, possible workarounds include:

  • Custom export or reporting logic to mask usernames
  • Middleware based anonymization before displaying data
  • Submitting a feature request via the SAP Influence Portal

I hope this helps provide clarity for your customer. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Chris

Response of the ODATA API :

<d:AddressUsageCode>BILL_TO</d:AddressUsageCode> (JSON :  "AddressUsageCode": "BILL_TO")
or <d:AddressUsageCode>XXDEFAULT</d:AddressUsageCode>(Json : "AddressUsageCode": "XXDEFAULT")


Regards,
Harshal

entry.title: Re: Best Practise in SAP Process Intelligence
entry.content:
Hi @CP_PL 

Thank you for your question.

Currently, SAP Process Intelligence does not support direct import of SAP Best Practices (for example BD9 Sell from Stock) from SAP Insights or Process Navigator.

However, you can still perform a fit-gap analysis by:

  • Accessing the best-practice content via SAP Process Navigator
  • Comparing it manually against your actual processes in Process Intelligence
  • Optionally you can also use Signavio Process Explorer for modelling best-practice flows

I hope this helps provide clarity for your customer. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Accelerate Your SAP S/4HANA Journey with Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE)
entry.content:
Accelerate Your SAP S/4HANA Journey with Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE)

This article is the first in a series exploring Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE). In upcoming article, we will dive into methodology, scenario selection, tooling, and more to demystify SDTE and showcase its value.

Modern enterprises are under constant pressure to innovate and optimize. For those running on SAP ERP, transitioning to SAP S/4HANA is a significant milestone - but how can you preserve your past investments that give you a competitive edge while embracing the latest technology and use the chance to optimize processes? SAP S/4HANA Selective Data Transition Engagement (SDTE) is specifically designed to address this challenge. By retaining what sets you apart, and standardizing areas where it makes sense, SDTE offers a flexible, efficient path to transformation.

 

Business Challenge

Balancing Differentiation and Standardization

Enterprises running SAP ERP have often spent years - or even decades - developing custom processes, industry-specific extensions, and unique reporting. These innovations are competitive differentiators that users rely on every day. At the same time, core "commodity" processes (Finance, Procurement, Manufacturing, HR) can gain dramatically from standardized best practices baked into SAP S/4HANA. The fundamental tension: How do you preserve what sets you apart while embracing the efficiency and innovation that come with a modern digital core?

Reducing IT Burden and TCO

Maintaining multiple legacy systems - each with its own data archives - drives up infrastructure costs, complicates backups and restores, and hampers analytics. As organizations plan moves to cloud offerings like RISE with SAP, every gigabyte contributes to ongoing subscription and storage expenses. Selective data transition helps by consolidating landscapes, cleansing aged records, and migrating only what truly matters - slashing total cost of ownership (TCO).

Ensuring Business Continuity

Prolonged downtime windows and sprawling, multi-year pre-projects erode user confidence and delay the realization of business benefits. CIOs, CFOs, enterprise architects, and process owners all share one goal: modernize without bringing the business to a halt. An effective migration strategy must keep business impact to a bare minimum while delivering a future-proof digital core.

 

The SDTE Solution - A Flexible, Targeted Approach

Unlike a one-size-fits-all implementation or a straightforward system conversion, SDTE offers a customer-specific roadmap:

  • Selectively Retain Data that remains relevant for analysis or compliance, while discarding obsolete or low-value data.
  • Incorporate Process Harmonization right away, without needing to spin off separate, time-consuming pre-projects.
  • Preservation of Custom Differentiators Carry forward the custom processes and extensions that users depend on, while standardizing commodity processes to leverage SAP S/4HANA best practices.
  • Adopt Modern, Standardized Practices for commodity processes, speeding up efficiency gains in finance, supply chain, and beyond.

Reduce System Footprint for the Cloud

When you move to the cloud, every gigabyte matters. By migrating only the relevant data, you can effectively reduce system footprint, cut storage costs, and ensure you don't drag inefficiencies into your new SAP S/4HANA landscape. At the same time, you'll feed AI-driven scenarios with the best, most accurate historical data - enabling predictive maintenance, more refined demand planning, or improved financial forecasting.

Consolidate Landscapes and Unlock Value

SDTE also excels at landscape consolidation - merging multiple ERP systems into a single SAP S/4HANA instance. This not only simplifies ongoing maintenance and upgrades but also improves transparency for reporting and analytics. Companies that take advantage of this flexibility experience significant cost savings and faster ROI.

Faster Time-to-Value

A hallmark of SDTE is its ability to eliminate or shorten many pre-projects, such as separately addressing finance harmonization or data cleansing. Because these transformations can be integrated into the main migration event, your organization realizes business benefits more quickly - with less effort from end users and fewer touchpoints for potential disruption.

 

Technical Detail

How Does the Engagement Work?

SDTE projects build on SAP Activate, enriched with SDTE-specific checkpoints:

  1. Discover
    Your business processes, data volumes, and future vision are analyzed to see what exactly needs to be transformed or left behind.
  2. Prepare
    A targeted plan is set up, detailing which data to migrate or cleanse. Tools and technical environments are installed to enable secure, high-performance data transfers.
  3. Explore and Realize
    Agile iterations test the migration rules, verifying that the relevant data is selected and transformed. Customizations are preserved where necessary, and processes are standardized where they are beneficial.
  4. Deploy/Run
    With SDTE variety of data migration approaches including minimized downtime approaches, your move to SAP S/4HANA can be scheduled over a weekend or other minimal business-impact window. Rigorous testing ensures everything functions smoothly.
  5. Quality Gates
    Throughout these phases, SDTE methodology includes checkpoints to maintain high standards, reduce risk, and ensure you are on track.

 

Tools, Principles, and Best Practices

  • Flexible Migration Approach: SDTE supports multiple different migration approaches like posting and table based. By default high-speed data transfer that bypasses application-level constraints, letting you harmonize or map data according to your new structures and preserve historical data.
  • Integration of Cleansing and Enrichment: Legacy data can be enriched, ensuring that your new system fuels modern capabilities like AI and advanced analytics.
  • System Landscape Consolidation: SDTE partners bring proven methods to merge or split SAP systems, helping you standardize reporting, unify master data, and gain complete transparency.

 

Success Stories

Pharmaceutical Company (Global): Data Footprint Reduction and Faster Time-to-Value

Customer consolidated an 85 TB ECC environment into a streamlined S/4HANA landscape, selectively retaining five years of history (down from 27) and migrating just 427 of 1,100 company codes. By combining landscape consolidation, selective retention, and finance harmonization in a single project, the customer accelerated value delivery and minimized disruption.

SDTE Properties in Action:

  • Landscape Consolidation: Multiple organizational units merged into one unified system.
  • Data Footprint Reduction: Historical data pruned by 80%, shrinking the HANA footprint.
  • Faster Time-to-Value: Combined disparate initiatives into one go-live event.

Chemicals Company (Japan): Phase approach and Full migration of historical data

The transition to the new system required migrating full historical data, including data archives from the SAP ERP application to SAP S/4HANA to realize data continuity for a set of company codes. Furthermore, the customer had to plan for and then execute various data conversions and codification changes in its general ledger accounts, materials numbers, profit centers, and so on to meet the data management requirements of the new system

SDTE Properties in Action:

  • Selective Data Retention: Only a set of company codes moved, legacy archives remained untouched.
  • Phased approach: Project split in multiple phases allowing flexibility and reducing the impact on the customer team,
  • Process Harmonization: various data conversions in general ledger accounts, materials numbers, profit centers to meet the data management requirements of the new system

 

Vision: The Future of Data Migration and Beyond

AI-Driven Efficiency

As artificial intelligence evolves, expect even more automation of data mapping, cleansing, and harmonization. AI can swiftly identify inconsistencies, propose corrective actions, and optimize transformations - lowering manual effort and reducing errors.

Standardization at Scale

With AI and continuous improvement, standards for data migration become more universal, making it easier to share best practices and lessons learned. This streamlines future transformations while reducing costs and risks.

Addressing the Resource Shortage

IT transformation skills are scarce, but AI-driven acceleration can help bridge the gap. Automated rule generation and scenario testing mean teams can get more done with fewer specialized resources.

As a result, IT can shift from a cost center to a genuine business enabler - fueling innovation rather than being bogged down by legacy systems.

 

Call to Action

You have seen how SDTE preserves your unique differentiators, modernizes core processes, and accelerates your move to a lean, cloud-ready SAP S/4HANA environment - while laying the foundation for AI-powered operational excellence.

Next in our series: As SDT encompasses a variety of pathways rather than a single one, our upcoming article will explore SDT Scenario Selection, focusing on:

  • SDT Scenarios Overview: Discussing the best practice SDT scenarios that are available and commonly used in projects.
  • Key Decision Drivers: Identifying the factors that influence the selection of the optimal SDT scenario for your transformation

In the meantime:

  1. Explore Webinars and Resources
    Discover more about SDTE via official SAP Support Portal webinars or community sessions that dive deeper into the specifics.
  2. Contact the SDTE Community
    Reach out to the expert group of SAP and its partners for an assessment of your current landscape. They can help identify how selective data transition can best fit your needs.
  3. Start Your Transformation
    Do not wait until maintenance windows close or all experts are not available anymore. A well-planned selective data migration can future-proof your IT environment and jump-start your intelligent enterprise journey.

Take the next step by visiting
SDTE Engagement Overview
to connect with the SDTE community and chart out your custom path to SAP S/4HANA success.
